message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that blocks the ability of the kidneys to reabsorb glucose, causing glucose to be excreted in the urine. Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonist that stimulates insulin secretion, Glyburide stimulates insulin secretion by blocking ATP-sensitive potassium channels, and Metformin decreases glucose production in the liver and improves insulin sensitivity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that blocks the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to glucose wasting in the urine. Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist that stimulates insulin secretion and inhibits glucagon secretion. Glyburide is a sulfonylurea that stimulates insulin secretion. Metformin decreases hepatic glucose production and increases insulin sensitivity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that works by blocking the ability of kidneys to reabsorb glucose and causes glucose wastage in urine is Canagliflozin. Exenatide, Glyburide, and Metformin work through different mechanisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Canagliflozin works by inhibiting SGLT2, a protein responsible for glucose reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to glucose being excreted in the urine. The other options work through different mechanisms, such as increasing insulin secretion (Exenatide), stimulating insulin release and reducing glucose production by the liver (Glyburide), and reducing glucose production by the liver and improving insulin sensitivity in the body (Metformin).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, which blocks the reabsorption of glucose by the kidneys and causes glucose wasting in the urine. The other options have different mechanisms of action, such as stimulating insulin secretion (Exenatide), increasing insulin sensitivity (Metformin), or inhibiting ATP-sensitive potassium channels in the pancreas (Glyburide).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitor, which blocks the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys and causes glucose to be excreted in the urine, leading to lower blood glucose levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin works by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to increased glucose excretion in urine. Exenatide stimulates insulin secretion, Glyburide stimulates the pancreas to release insulin, and Metformin reduces glucose production in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The medication that works by blocking the ability of the kidney to reabsorb glucose and causes glucose wasting in the urine is Canagliflozin. Exenatide works by increasing insulin secretion, Glyburide stimulates the release of insulin from the pancreas, and Metformin decreases glucose production in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin works by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidneys, leading to glucose loss in the urine. Exenatide stimulates insulin release, Glyburide stimulates insulin secretion, and Metformin decreases gluconeogenesis in the liver.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Canagliflozin works by blocking the reabsorption of glucose in the kidney and causing glucose to be excreted in urine. Exenatide works by increasing insulin secretion and decreasing glucose production, Glyburide stimulates insulin secretion, and Metformin decreases glucose production and improves insulin sensitivity.
